awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Advanced Quantitative and Computational Methods for STEM Education Research
awd_abstract_narration:
The goals of this capacity building institute are (a) to introduce participants to rigorous and novel applications of advanced methods to STEM education research, (b) to provide them with continuous methodological support in research planning, data analysis, and publication, and (c) to create a community that prepares emerging scholars for taking leadership in advancing STEM education research. This capacity building award initiates an institute in quantitative and computational methods for STEM education research through a collaboration between researchers at the University of Chicago and those at Michigan State University. Through launching a national campaign of recruitment, the team will select a diverse cohort of NSF Fellows of STEM Education Research among early- and mid-career scholars, especially those from under-represented backgrounds. 

Instructors and Fellows will critically evaluate existing STEM education research throughout six courses over the summers in year 1 and year 2. Institute training will focus on (1) research designs and causal inference, (2) measurement, (3) social network analysis, (4) multilevel modeling, (5) causal mediation analysis, and (6) computational methods for analyzing qualitative and social media data. Structured discussions of Fellows’ ongoing studies will be supplemented by guest speaker presentations and round-table discussions. Fellows will present their capstone projects and further develop research collaborations in the summer of year 3. A customized website will disseminate to the broader STEM education research community.

This research institute is funded by ECR (the core research program of the Education and Human Resources directorate) and attends specifically to critical aspects in research capacity building.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcomes Report

Award Title: Collaborative Research: Advanced Quantitative and Computational Methods for STEM Education Research

Federal Award ID: 2025259

With funding from the NSF from September 1, 2020 through August 31, 2024, we established the Summer Institute in Advanced Quantitative and Computational Methods for STEM Education Research (SIARM for STEM) through a collaborative effort between researchers at the University of Chicago and Michigan State University. The primary goal of this institute was to train a distinguished cohort of early- and mid-career scholars, emphasizing strong representation from diverse backgrounds, to become leaders in applying advanced quantitative and computational methods to STEM education research.

Our nationwide recruitment campaign resulted in the selection of 29 fellows who brought a wealth of diversity in terms of demographic background, disciplinary training, career stage, institutional affiliation, and expertise in various STEM fields. Among the fellows, 15 identified as Black, 7 as Hispanic or multiracial, 5 as other, and 1 as a person with a disability. Additionally, 13 fellows were affiliated with minority-serving institutions. This rich diversity greatly enhanced the institute's environment and contributed to a broad spectrum of research projects addressing critical themes in STEM education, positioning the group collectively to demonstrate significant leadership potential in the field of STEM education research.

The institute successfully achieved several key objectives by (a) introducing fellows to up-to-date concepts and a comprehensive array of rigorous techniques with novel applications to STEM education research, (b) providing continuous methodological support in research planning, data analysis, and publications, and (c) creating opportunities for interaction among scholars with shared interests. Through this training grant, fellows have been able to expand their professional networks, develop research collaborations, and extend strong support to one another. The quantitative training provided was highly impactful in that about 70% of the fellows reported a significant enhancement in their understanding and use of quantitative methods, and many have successfully translated this knowledge into research products disseminated within their professional communities. In addition, the collaborative and supportive environment fostered by the institute led to impressive individual milestones during the grant period; at least 11 fellows were promoted through the ranks at their respective institutions and at least 22 fellows received research grants from various funding agencies. To this date, four fellows in this cohort have received prestigious NSF CAREER awards. See https://voices.uchicago.edu/nsf-siarm/our-fellows/ for further details.

In addition to the individual accomplishments, a vibrant community has developed among the fellows, instructors, and advisory board members. Initially, few of the fellows knew each other, with instructors playing a central role in the network. However, following our annual summer institutes, the fellows themselves became more central to this network, taking on key roles in its integration and coordination. This emerging community has been instrumental in fostering collaborations, leading to new proposals, papers, and projects. The network has also facilitated valuable connections between the relatively junior fellows and the senior scholars on our advisory board, who offered career advice, substantive feedback, and extended networking opportunities beyond the institute.

Furthermore, the institute provided continuous support to the fellows as they made significant strides in research on fostering a more inclusive culture of STEM teaching and learning. The research projects focused on equalizing access to STEM learning opportunities, enhancing classroom pedagogy, and addressing organizational constraints on learning opportunities. These endeavors culminated in the final-year conference on “Quantitative Methods for Assessing the Potential to Disrupt Disparities in and through STEM Education” in Summer 2024 (https://voices.uchicago.edu/nsf-siarm/june-2024-conference/). The agenda-setting discussions and the collective efforts are expected to contribute to a broader sense of belonging among STEM learners and experts and greater capacity among STEM education researchers for producing high quality evidence that informs policies and practices.

Several valuable lessons emerged from our experience that will benefit future institutes. Effective community building requires outreach across diverse institutions and networks. Establishing a multidisciplinary and diverse advisory board that includes leading minority scholars and representatives from minority-serving institutions and funding agencies is crucial for providing guidance. Supporting new learning through authentic projects and research enhances the effectiveness of training. Finally, understanding that the application of statistical methods is context-dependent highlights the importance of addressing specific challenges in educational research.

In conclusion, the institute has made significant progress in advancing the field of STEM education research and supporting underrepresented groups in STEM. This dynamic community of scholars is actively contributing to new research and collaborations. The lessons learned from this project will continue to inform and enhance future efforts, positioning this group well to demonstrate leadership potential in the field of STEM education research.
